item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: One‐Pot Synthesis of Ferrocene Thioamides from Ferrocenecarboxaldehyde via the Willgerodt–Kindler Reaction
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A series of ferrocene thioamides is synthesized via Willgerodt–Kindler reaction from ferrocenecarboxaldehyde. Two experimental protocols are developed to effectively employ both primary and secondary amines. The solvent screening reveals a highly positive effect of amide solvent on the reaction. Mechanistic study helps to elucidate the role of Na2S as promoted rather than the catalyst.
Ferrocene thioamides are potential alternatives for classical oxoamide‐type ferrocene ligands with broad applications in metal‐catalyzed transformations as well as substrates for CH activations and applications in other fields. A reaction of ferrocenecarboxaldehyde with various amines and sulfur promoted by sodium sulfide furnishes a wide range of ferrocene thioamides via the Willgerodt–Kindler multicomponent reaction. The detailed solvent screening reveals that amide‐type solvents are highly beneficial for the reaction. The steric hindrance of bulky amine substrates limits the reaction. While secondary amines require only conventional heating, primary amines yield better results with microwave irradiation at higher temperatures. The mechanism is investigated using nuclear magnetic resonance kinetic measurements, which show that Na2S acts as a promoter, rather than a catalyst, of the reaction.
item.content:encoded:

Two experimental protocols are developed to effectively employ both primary and secondary amines. The solvent screening reveals a highly positive effect of amide solvent on the reaction. Mechanistic study helps to elucidate the role of Na2S as promoted rather than the catalyst.


Ferrocene thioamides are potential alternatives for classical oxoamide-type ferrocene ligands with broad applications in metal-catalyzed transformations as well as substrates for CH activations and applications in other fields. A reaction of ferrocenecarboxaldehyde with various amines and sulfur promoted by sodium sulfide furnishes a wide range of ferrocene thioamides via the Willgerodt–Kindler multicomponent reaction. The detailed solvent screening reveals that amide-type solvents are highly beneficial for the reaction. The steric hindrance of bulky amine substrates limits the reaction. While secondary amines require only conventional heating, primary amines yield better results with microwave irradiation at higher temperatures. The mechanism is investigated using nuclear magnetic resonance kinetic measurements, which show that Na2S acts as a promoter, rather than a catalyst, of the reaction.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Vicinal Pyrazolyl‐Phosphine Imines and their Palladium Complexes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Pyrazolyl phosphines bearing a vicinal aminal group are synthesized and hydrolyzed to formyl derivatives and cyclic phosphonium salts, with product ratios depending on HCl concentration. The corresponding methylimines act as bidentate ligands forming Pd(II) complexes, while phosphonium salts afford a Pd(IV) complex confirmed by X‐ray crystallography.
Readily available 4‐bromo‐5‐(N,N,N′‐trimethyl‐N‐(trimethylsilyl)diamino‐methyl)pyrazoles are employed as starting materials for the synthesis of pyrazolyl phosphines. Subsequent hydrolysis yields the expected 4‐diphenylphosphino‐5‐formylpyrazoles, accompanied by the formation of cyclic phosphonium salts. The product distribution is found to depend on the concentration of hydrochloric acid: higher acid concentrations favored the formation of cyclic phosphonium salts. A similar behavior is observed for the methylimines derived from 4‐diphenylphosphino‐5‐formylpyrazoles. These imines acted as bidentate ligands, readily forming palladium(II) complexes. In contrast, the cyclic phosphonium salts reacted with dichlorobis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) to afford a palladium(IV) complex, the structure of which is confirmed by X‐ray crystallography.

Readily available 4-bromo-5-(N,N,N′-trimethyl-N-(trimethylsilyl)diamino-methyl)pyrazoles are employed as starting materials for the synthesis of pyrazolyl phosphines. Subsequent hydrolysis yields the expected 4-diphenylphosphino-5-formylpyrazoles, accompanied by the formation of cyclic phosphonium salts. In contrast, the cyclic phosphonium salts reacted with dichlorobis(triphenylphosphine)palladium(II) to afford a palladium(IV) complex, the structure of which is confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

item.title: Electrochemical α‐Hydroxymethylation of Aryl Ketones with Methanol
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
β‐hydroxy ketones represent a class of compounds with broad applications in pharmaceuticals and bioactive molecules. However, the synthesis of these compounds often encounters various challenges. Herein, an electrochemical method is reported that utilizes methanol as a C1 source, enabling the α‐hydroxymethylation of a series of aryl ketones under oxidant‐free conditions. This approach achieves high yields and exhibits broad substrate compatibility.
β‐hydroxy ketones represent a class of compounds with broad applications in pharmaceuticals and bioactive molecules. However, the synthesis of these compounds often encounters various challenges. Herein, an electrochemical method is reported that utilizes methanol as a C1 source, enabling the α‐hydroxymethylation of a series of aryl ketones under oxidant‐free conditions for constructing β‐hydroxy ketones. This approach achieves high yields and exhibits broad substrate compatibility. Mechanistic investigations indicate that the reaction proceeds via a radical pathway, rather than through conventional methanol oxidation to formaldehyde.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Toward Novel Trifluoromethylated Peptidomimetics: A Case Study of Cathepsin C Inhibitors
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A series of CF3‐containing amino acid analogues is prepared and studied by docking to Cathepsin C. The results highlight their potential as peptidomimetics and showcase the value of fluorination in drug design.
Herein, both synthetic and theoretical results related to the development of amino acid analogues containing a CF3‐olefinic moiety and their evaluation as potential inhibitors of Cathepsin C are presented. The key synthetic steps include the trifluoromethylation using the Ruppert–Prakash reagent and a Horner–Wadsworth–Emmons olefination to obtain the desired CF3‐alkenyl amino acid derivatives. In recent years, theoretical approaches based on molecular docking have gained significant attention for predicting the biological activity of synthetic compounds as enzyme inhibitors. The research specifically targets Cathepsin C, also known as dipeptidyl peptidase I, a protease that plays a crucial role in activating various degradative enzymes involved in tissue damage during inflammatory diseases.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Convenient Synthesis of C‐Linked β‐D‐Galactosides with Lipophilic Aglycone Component Toward Lectin A Inhibition and Antibiofilm Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an ESKAPE pathogen, relies on lectin A (LecA) for adhesion, biofilm formation, and virulence making it a promising therapeutic target. Hydrolytically stable novel C‐linked monovalent D‐galactosides A, B, and C with lipophilic aglycone component are synthesized using Weinreb‐amide‐based building block 15 and are evaluated for bacterial biofilm inhibition activity.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a member of the World Health Organization‐listed ESKAPE pathogens, exhibits high drug resistance and relies on the galactose‐specific lectin LecA for adhesion, biofilm formation, and virulence. Targeting lectin A (LecA) emerges as a promising antivirulence strategy. While multivalent D‐galactoside derivatives demonstrate strong LecA binding and biofilm disruption, their high molecular weight, synthetic complexity, and poor pharmacokinetic profiles limit clinical potential. In contrast, monovalent β‐D‐galactosides with aromatic aglycons offer improved drug‐likeness and bioavailability, though typically with moderate potency. The hydrophobic pocket adjacent to LecA's binding site inspires lipophilic modifications to enhance activity, yet most inhibitors remain O‐ or S‐linked glycosides. C‐linked β‐D‐galactosides, which are hydrolytically more stable, remain underexplored. Motivated by their potential advantages, the design and synthesis of hitherto unreported monovalent C‐linked β‐D‐galactoside ligands with aryl aglycones, represented by general structures A, B, and C, is proposed as new LecA inhibitors for combating P. aeruginosa biofilm.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Electrocatalytic CH Annulation of Alkynes to Functionalized Heterocycles: Synthesis and Mechanical Insights
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Electrochemical CH annulation of alkynes represents a sustainable and efficient pathway for constructing functionalized heterocycles. This work highlights, how alkyne integration enables the creation of nitrogen‐ and oxygen‐containing scaffolds with adaptable features for pharmaceuticals, materials, and catalysis. Integrating transition‐metal and metal‐free electrocatalysis, this overviews the selective and eco‐friendly routes for redefining heterocycle synthesis through controlled alkyne activation.
Heterocyclic frameworks are indispensable in pharmaceuticals, advanced materials, and catalysis owing to their diverse structures and wide‐ranging functionalities. In recent years, electrochemical CH annulation using alkynes has emerged as a green and selective platform for the efficient construction of these complex systems. By avoiding stoichiometric oxidants and enabling reagent‐free processes, this methodology reduces environmental impact while improving synthetic efficiency. Alkyne incorporation plays a pivotal role in modulating the electronic and biological properties of nitrogen‐ and oxygen‐rich heterocycles, which are prominent in bioactive compounds. Innovations in electro‐oxidative processes and transition‐metal catalysis have significantly advanced the field, allowing for precise and sustainable transformations. Herein, the synthesis of functionalized heterocycles employing annulation of alkynes electrocatalytically, role of catalysts, and mechanistic insights are overviewed by critically investigating the recent progress in crafting next‐generation heterocyclic scaffolds with functional versatility.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Hypervalent‐Iodine‐Mediated Synthesis of Sulfinamides from Sulfenamides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An efficient approach to sulfinamides from sulfenamides is developed by using PhI(OAc)2/H2O, which features mild and metal‐free conditions, high to excellent yields, and good functional group compatibility. In particular, the products obtained can be readily converted into many potentially bioactive sulfur‐containing compounds.
A concise approach to access sulfinamides from sulfenamides is developed by using PhI(OAc)2/H2O. This protocol features mild and metal‐free conditions, high to excellent yields, and good functional group compatibility and provides an efficient and green route to sulfinamide derivatives. Importantly, the products obtained can be readily converted into potentially bioactive sulfonamides, sulfilimines, sulfonimidoyl halides, and sulfinimidate compounds for medicinal research, thus exhibiting diversified synthetic potential.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iodine‐Catalyzed C3–H Sulfinylation of Indoles with Sulfenamides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This study proposes an efficient iodine‐catalyzed C3–H sulfinylation of indoles, employing sulfenamides as sustainable sulfur sources under transition‐metal‐ and oxidant‐free conditions.
Organic sulfides, particularly 3‐sulfinylindoles, have garnered substantial attention owing to their remarkable pharmacological activities and broad applications in materials science and pesticide chemistry. Nevertheless, traditional synthetic approaches for 3‐sulfinylindoles usually suffer from drawbacks such as toxic reagents, dependence on transition‐metal catalysts, and severe reaction conditions. Herein, an iodine‐catalyzed C3–H sulfinylation strategy is presented for the synthesis of 3‐sulfinylindoles, employing sulfenamides as stable and odorless sulfenylating reagents. This protocol proceeds under mild conditions (100 °C in 1,2‐dichloroethane) without extra oxidants or additives, delivering a broad range of 3‐sulfinylindole derivatives in moderate to excellent yields. Substrate scope investigations demonstrate excellent compatibility with indoles having electron‐donating/withdrawing groups and sulfenamides containing aromatic/heterocyclic groups. This method addresses critical challenges in traditional sulfinylation, providing a green, metal‐free, and efficient approach for the construction of thiofunctionalized indole derivatives with potential applications in drug discovery and functional materials.
item.content:encoded:
This study proposes an efficient iodine-catalyzed C3–H sulfinylation of indoles, employing sulfenamides as sustainable sulfur sources under transition-metal- and oxidant-free conditions.


Organic sulfides, particularly 3-sulfinylindoles, have garnered substantial attention owing to their remarkable pharmacological activities and broad applications in materials science and pesticide chemistry. Nevertheless, traditional synthetic approaches for 3-sulfinylindoles usually suffer from drawbacks such as toxic reagents, dependence on transition-metal catalysts, and severe reaction conditions. Herein, an iodine-catalyzed C3–H sulfinylation strategy is presented for the synthesis of 3-sulfinylindoles, employing sulfenamides as stable and odorless sulfenylating reagents. This protocol proceeds under mild conditions (100 °C in 1,2-dichloroethane) without extra oxidants or additives, delivering a broad range of 3-sulfinylindole derivatives in moderate to excellent yields. Substrate scope investigations demonstrate excellent compatibility with indoles having electron-donating/withdrawing groups and sulfenamides containing aromatic/heterocyclic groups. This method addresses critical challenges in traditional sulfinylation, providing a green, metal-free, and efficient approach for the construction of thiofunctionalized indole derivatives with potential applications in drug discovery and functional materials.
item.dc:creator: Liting Yang, Xiaoxu Xu, Huiru Pan, Yikai Zhang, Shuyu Lai, Xinyu Cao, Yanjie Wang, Guoqun Liu, Xiao Hong, Xiangtao Kong, Huijie Qiao, Mingli Jiao
item.dc:title: Iodine‐Catalyzed C3–H Sulfinylation of Indoles with Sulfenamides

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthetic Access to the Class of 3‐Amino‐4‐Cyano‐Substituted Thiophenes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The synthesis of 1,1‐dibromo‐3,4,4‐trichloro‐2‐cyano‐1,3‐butadiene opens a first pathway to 3‐amino‐4‐cyano‐thiophenes. These compounds display a push–pull substitution pattern that allows for selective modifications at the 2 and 5 positions. Through S‐oxidation, substitution, and reduction valuable halo and hydrothiophenes are generated, which could be serve as important monomers for the development of highly conductive polythiophenes, while maintaining their essential 3‐push‐4‐pull structural characteristic.
The synthesis of 1,1‐dibromo‐3,4,4‐trichloro‐2‐cyano‐1,3‐butadiene (3) provides a selective access to the new class of 3‐amino‐4‐cyano‐thiophenes 2. The unique push–pull substitution pattern of 2 allows a chemoselective modification in the 2 and 5 positions. Derivatization of 2 is accomplished by selective S‐oxidation of the vinylsulfanyl unit. Substitution of the resulting vinylsulfinyl group of 14 by halogen nucleophiles led to dihalothiophenes 16 and 17 in good yields. A subsequent selective dehalogenation in the 2 and 5 positions is accomplished, leaving the 3,4‐push–pull unit untouched. The new 2,5‐dihalothiophenes, as well as the 2,5‐unsubstituted thiophene 20, are interesting monomers for the preparation of highly conducting polythiophenes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Multicomponent Strategy for the Synthesis of 2,3‐Dihydro‐4H‐Imidazol‐4‐Ones under Catalyst‐ and Additive‐Free Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A catalyst‐ and additive‐free multicomponent reaction is developed to synthesize 2,3‐dihydro‐4H‐imidazol‐4‐ones using benzoylformates, ketones, and ammonium salts. It incorporates two nitrogen atoms from ammonium salts, forms four CN bonds in one pot, and shows broad substrate compatibility with yields ranging from 24% to 94%, aligning with green chemistry principles.
A catalyst‐ and additive‐free multicomponent reaction is developed for synthesizing substituted 2,3‐dihydro‐4H‐imidazol‐4‐ones from readily available benzoylformates, ketones, and ammonium salts. This protocol features dual nitrogen incorporation from ammonium salts and four CN bonds formation in one pot under optimized conditions. It exhibits broad substrate scope and good functionality tolerance, aligning with green chemistry principles.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: π‐Conjugated 2‐Arylindoles with High Quantum Yields and Tunable Spectroscopic Features
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
New π‐conjugated 2‐arylindole‐based fluorophores bearing (hetero)aryleneethynylene units and a pendant ester group are prepared. These show high fluorescence quantum yields (up to 94%) and solvatochromic effects. The ester moiety allows easy access to other functional groups, such as an N‐hydroxysuccinimide whose reactivity can be exploited for proteins and antibodies bioconjugation.
Indole‐based fluorophores represent a promising class of fluorescent probes due to their tunable optical properties, structural versatility, and compatibility with biological systems. In this work, the design, synthesis, and photophysical characterization of a new series of 2‐arylindole derivatives functionalized with (hetero)aryleneethynylene units and a pendant ester group are reported. The compounds are synthesized via Fischer indole synthesis followed by Sonogashira coupling, enabling also the introduction of electron‐donating (–NMe2) and electron‐withdrawing (–CN) substituents. Furthermore, they are decorated with an N‐hydroxysuccinimidyl (NHS) moiety for facile bioconjugation. Spectroscopic studies conducted in solvents of varying polarity reveal strong solvatochromic effects, high fluorescence quantum yields (up to 94%), and emission wavelengths spanning the blue to green region. Selected derivatives are successfully conjugated to bovine serum albumin, thanks to the NHS reactive group. Photophysical measurements of the resulting protein conjugates reveal that the fluorophores remain solvent‐exposed, maintaining their emission profiles in aqueous media—an important feature for potential bioimaging and sensing applications. These findings highlight the utility of indole‐based scaffolds for the development of environmentally responsive fluorescent probes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Salt‐Free CatAnionic Vesicular Nanoreactor from Dithiocarbamate: Michael Addition of Nitroolefins in Water
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A salt‐free CatAnionic vesicular nanoreactor is developed from dithiocarbamate amphiphiles via a simple one‐step synthesis. These self‐assembled vesicles catalyze aqueous Michael additions with high efficiency, enable one‐pot transformations, and demonstrate reusability and recyclability, providing a sustainable approach for organic synthesis and pharmaceutical intermediate preparation.
The salt‐free CatAnionic vesicle is previously generated by mixing cationic and anionic amphiphiles and removing the salt that occurred as a byproduct from the mixture. In this study, a new strategy to produce the salt‐free CatAnionic vesicle of N,N‐dialkylammonium N,N‐dialkyldithiocarbamate (AmDTC) is reported through a one‐step condensation between secondary amine and CS2. The AmDTC dispersed in water, resulting in the spontaneous formation of salt‐free CatAnionic vesicles. Among several AmDTCs, the N,N‐didodecylammonium N,N‐didodecyldithiocarbamate (AmDTC‐C12) showed high stability and is applied as a vesicular nanoreactor for the Michael addition in water. These vesicles catalyzed aqueous Michael additions of nitroolefins, affording 23 adducts in 65%–92% yields. The vesicles enabled preparative‐scale and one‐pot Michael addition by in situ generation of AmDTC‐C12 vesicle afforded the Michael adducts also in good yields. The AmDTC‐C12 vesicular nanoreactor is applied for the synthesis of (±)‐baclofen with 54% yields over three steps. Reusability of the AmDTC‐C12 is demonstrated and allowed the reuse up to seven cycles. Finally, chemical recycling of N,N‐didodecylamine precursor is demonstrated by converting AmDTC‐C12 to N,N‐didodecylammonium chloride salt by simple acidification. Owing to their simple precursors and mild synthesis, salt‐free CatAnionic vesicles from AmDTC show promising and untapped potentials as organocatalysts and delivery applications.

In this study, a new strategy to produce the salt-free CatAnionic vesicle of N,N-dialkylammonium N,N-dialkyldithiocarbamate (AmDTC) is reported through a one-step condensation between secondary amine and CS2. Among several AmDTCs, the N,N-didodecylammonium N,N-didodecyldithiocarbamate (AmDTC-C12) showed high stability and is applied as a vesicular nanoreactor for the Michael addition in water. item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Mechanochemical Nickel‐Catalyzed Suzuki–Miyaura Cross‐Coupling of Phenol‐Derived Cyanate Esters
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A mechanochemical strategy has been developed for the nickel‐catalyzed Suzuki–Miyaura cross‐coupling of cyano esters derived from phenol, as electrophilic substrates using arylboronic acids via Csp2O bond cleavage.
A mechanochemical strategy has been developed for the nickel‐catalyzed Suzuki–Miyaura cross‐coupling of cyano esters derived from phenols, as electrophilic substrates using arylboronic acids via Csp2O bond cleavage. This approach capitalizes on the abundance of phenols, using cyano‐functionalized derivatives to enable high reactivity and functional group compatibility without halogenated reagents. The reaction is carried out under solvent‐free, temperature‐trace conditions, significantly reducing environmental impact. The methodology offers a sustainable and scalable alternative for biaryl synthesis, with implications for pharmaceutical and material sciences.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A Practical and Scalable Synthesis of Cyclized and Uncyclized Xanthene‐1,8‐Dione Derivatives Using Cyanuric Chloride as a Green Organocatalyst
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A practical and eco‐friendly approach for the synthesis of 1,8‐dioxo‐octahydroxanthene derivatives is described, employing water as the sole solvent under mild, metal‐free conditions. This versatile protocol delivers both uncyclized and cyclized products with good to excellent yields, broad substrate scope, and superior green chemistry metrics with low E‐factor, making it a valuable contribution to sustainable synthetic methodologies.
A mild, water‐mediated protocol has been developed for the synthesis of both uncyclized and cyclized 1,8‐dioxo‐octahydroxanthene derivatives under ambient conditions. Utilizing cyclic‐1,3‐dicarbonyl compounds and structurally diverse aromatic or heteroaromatic aldehydes, the transformation proceeds efficiently with cyanuric chloride (TCT) as a green organocatalyst. The reaction conditions are finely tunable, allowing selective access to either uncyclized intermediates or cyclized products by adjusting time and temperature, thereby enabling modular control over product outcomes. The protocol also demonstrates excellent compatibility with isatin derivatives, yielding spirooxindolo xanthenedione frameworks in high yields. Substrate scope evaluation revealed broad functional group tolerance, with several products displaying notable biological activities, including anticancer, antibacterial, and antileishmanial properties. All synthesized compounds are fully characterized using spectroscopic techniques such as 1H, 13C, and mass spectroscopy. A detailed, plausible mechanism for the transformation has also been proposed and discussed. Comprehensive green metrics, including atom economy, E‐factor, process mass intensity, and other metrics, are calculated for each cyclized derivative. Gram‐scale experiments further confirmed the scalability and environmental sustainability of this operationally simple, metal‐free, and energy‐efficient protocol.
item.content:encoded:

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Pyrrolo[2,1‐f][1,2,4]triazin‐4‐amine: Synthesis, C7‐Functionalization, and NH2‐Derivatization via Buchwald–Hartwig‐Type Coupling
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An optimized synthetic route and regioselective C7/NH2‐functionalization protocols for pyrrolo[2,1‐f][1,2,4]triazine‐4‐amine are disclosed, significantly enhancing accessibility and structural diversification of this relevant N‐heterocycle.
An optimized gram‐scale synthetic route to pyrrolo[2,1‐f][1,2,4]triazin‐4‐amine is reported, affording an overall yield of 85%. Furthermore, regioselective C7‐functionalization is achieved via both organometallic and direct strategies, whereas NH2‐derivatization proceeds through Buchwald–Hartwig‐type coupling, providing derivatives in isolated yields ranging from 8% to >99%. These advancements enhance synthetic accessibility and facilitate efficient structural diversification of this significant N‐heterocycle.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Cu(I)‐Catalyzed N‐Mono‐ and N,O‐Diallylation of Nitroaromatic Compounds Using Allylic Borane‐Amine Adducts
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
DABCO adduct of triallylic boranes in the presence of simple copper(I) catalyst transforms of nitroaromatics (including heteroaryls) to either N,O‐diallylated or N‐allylated hydroxylamines. This transformation possesses high selectivity and scalability, performs under mild conditions and controls by the addition of alcoholates.
Amine adducts of triallylic boranes reductively allylate nitroaromatic compounds in the presence of 1–5 mol% of phosphine‐ or NHC‐copper(I) complexes, yielding N,O‐diallylic hydroxylamines with high selectivity. The reaction rate is strongly dependent on the amine component of the adducts, with the DABCO adduct proving the most reactive. The effects of solvent, ligands, and temperature on yield and selectivity are investigated. Even sterically hindered nitroaromatics, such as 2,6‐dimethylnitrobenzene underwent selective monoallylation providing N‐allyl‐ and N‐(methallyl)hydroxylamines. The reaction's broad scope is demonstrated with 22 different nitroaromatics bearing both electron‐donating and electron‐withdrawing substituents and it is successfully scaled up to 6 grams. Allylation of 2‐allylnitrobenzene for mechanistic studies revealed the formation of indoline derivatives, indicating the involvement in the transformation of N‐centered radicals. This is further supported by the isolation of traces of bicyclic compounds derived from radical cyclizations during the reaction with nitrobenzene.
item.content:encoded:
DABCO adduct of triallylic boranes in the presence of simple copper(I) catalyst transforms of nitroaromatics (including heteroaryls) to either N,O-diallylated or N-allylated hydroxylamines. This transformation possesses high selectivity and scalability, performs under mild conditions and controls by the addition of alcoholates.


Amine adducts of triallylic boranes reductively allylate nitroaromatic compounds in the presence of 1–5 mol% of phosphine- or NHC-copper(I) complexes, yielding N,O-diallylic hydroxylamines with high selectivity. The reaction rate is strongly dependent on the amine component of the adducts, with the DABCO adduct proving the most reactive. The effects of solvent, ligands, and temperature on yield and selectivity are investigated. Even sterically hindered nitroaromatics, such as 2,6-dimethylnitrobenzene underwent selective monoallylation providing N-allyl- and N-(methallyl)hydroxylamines. The reaction's broad scope is demonstrated with 22 different nitroaromatics bearing both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents and it is successfully scaled up to 6 grams. Allylation of 2-allylnitrobenzene for mechanistic studies revealed the formation of indoline derivatives, indicating the involvement in the transformation of N-centered radicals. This is further supported by the isolation of traces of bicyclic compounds derived from radical cyclizations during the reaction with nitrobenzene.

item.dc:title: Cu(I)‐Catalyzed N‐Mono‐ and N,O‐Diallylation of Nitroaromatic Compounds Using Allylic Borane‐Amine Adducts

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Regioselective Synthesis of 3‐Benzoyl‐4‐Phenyl‐4H,5H‐Thiopyrano[2,3‐b]chromen‐5‐One Derivatives through One‐Pot Domino Reaction Using Aromatic Aldehyde, β‐Enaminone, and 4‐Hydroxy‐2H‐Chromene‐2‐Thione
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
An efficient, green, and regioselective one‐pot three‐component synthesis of thiopyranochromenones has been developed. It combines aromatic aldehydes and β‐enaminones with 4‐hydroxy‐2H‐chromene‐2‐thiones, using triphenylphosphine and N‐bromosuccinimide as mediators. Interestingly, triphenylphosphine acts as a catalyst, facilitating the formation of bromonium ions. This methodology stands out due to excellent yields and mild reaction conditions, making it a valuable contribution to existing synthetic protocols.
A green, efficient, and regioselective one‐pot three‐component synthesis of 3‐benzoyl‐4‐phenyl‐4H,5H‐thiopyrano [2,3‐b]chromen‐5‐one derivatives has been developed. This protocol utilizes 4‐hydroxy‐2H‐chromene‐2‐thione, aromatic aldehydes, and β‐enaminones, mediated by triphenylphosphine and N‐bromosuccinimide. Notably, this protocol involves a Michael‐type addition followed by intramolecular cyclization. This methodology offers excellent product yields under mild reaction conditions, making it a valuable addition to synthetic protocols.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Regioisomeric Effect on the Photocatalytic Properties of Photoluminescent Aromatic Cyano‐Methoxybenzenethioethers
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Organic donor−acceptor cyanoarenes have risen as potent, fine‐tunable photocatalysts. However, the structural effects of derivatives with thiophenol donors are poorly understood. Herein, the study and identification of some structure‐photocatalytic activity relationships of a regioisomeric series of methoxythiophenol‐cyanoarenes by evaluating them in two distinct model photoredox and energy transfer‐catalyzed reactions is presented.
Organic donor−acceptor photocatalysts are very appealing for the discovery and effective application in photocatalytic transformations, for which the understanding of the structural implications in their photoactivity is key for success. In this work, the structure‐photocatalytic activity relationship of a regioisomeric series of cyanoarene‐based systems bearing methoxythiophenol units as donor groups is presented. To this aim, their activity in two distinct photoredox and triplet‐triplet energy transfer (EnT)‐catalyzed reactions is evaluated. On the one hand, while all catalysts show good oxidizing properties in the excited state, photochemical partial degradation leading to a mixture of photoactive species hampers the correlation between the redox potentials of the initial species and the observed reactivity on a test photoredox reaction. On the other hand, two structure–property relationships could be identified in the case of the test EnT reaction. Thus, a para‐dicyanobenzene backbone leads to higher triplet energies, followed by the meta and ortho isomers, while meta‐methoxythiophenol donor groups prove more efficient for applications in EnT catalysis. Hence, this study allows for the identification of key structural features, as well as good candidates for each targeted reaction, showing the potential of aromatic thioethers as photocatalysts for a variety of light‐mediated processes.
item.content:encoded:
Organic donor−acceptor cyanoarenes have risen as potent, fine-tunable photocatalysts. However, the structural effects of derivatives with thiophenol donors are poorly understood. Herein, the study and identification of some structure-photocatalytic activity relationships of a regioisomeric series of methoxythiophenol-cyanoarenes by evaluating them in two distinct model photoredox and energy transfer-catalyzed reactions is presented.


Organic donor−acceptor photocatalysts are very appealing for the discovery and effective application in photocatalytic transformations, for which the understanding of the structural implications in their photoactivity is key for success. In this work, the structure-photocatalytic activity relationship of a regioisomeric series of cyanoarene-based systems bearing methoxythiophenol units as donor groups is presented. To this aim, their activity in two distinct photoredox and triplet-triplet energy transfer (EnT)-catalyzed reactions is evaluated. On the one hand, while all catalysts show good oxidizing properties in the excited state, photochemical partial degradation leading to a mixture of photoactive species hampers the correlation between the redox potentials of the initial species and the observed reactivity on a test photoredox reaction. On the other hand, two structure–property relationships could be identified in the case of the test EnT reaction. Thus, a para-dicyanobenzene backbone leads to higher triplet energies, followed by the meta and ortho isomers, while meta-methoxythiophenol donor groups prove more efficient for applications in EnT catalysis. Hence, this study allows for the identification of key structural features, as well as good candidates for each targeted reaction, showing the potential of aromatic thioethers as photocatalysts for a variety of light-mediated processes.

item.dc:title: Regioisomeric Effect on the Photocatalytic Properties of Photoluminescent Aromatic Cyano‐Methoxybenzenethioethers

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Unlocking the Potential of Ferrocene‐Functionalized Donor–π–Acceptor Systems with Phthalimide/Naphthalimide Acceptors for Non‐volatile Memory Devices
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Ferrocene‐based donor–acceptor (D–π–A) systems, incorporating ferrocene as the donor moiety connected by an acetylene linkage and functionalized with naphthalimide or phthalimide acceptor units, have been developed for nonvolatile resistive switching memory devices demonstrating stable binary write‐once‐read‐many memory characteristics.
A series of donor–π–acceptor (D–π–A) push‐pull compounds incorporating ferrocene as the electron donor and phthalimide/naphthalimide as electron acceptors are designed and synthesized for nonvolatile memory applications. These compounds exhibit excellent solubility in common organic solvents, ensuring suitability for solution‐processed device fabrication. The strong donor–acceptor interactions in the D–π–A architecture enable efficient charge injection and transfer, essential for write‐once‐read‐many memory behavior. Among the synthesized compounds, a naphthalimide derivative with a trimethoxyphenyl substituent shows superior performance, with a low threshold voltage of −1.1 V, a high ON/OFF ratio (≈104), and a retention time of 2000 s. Systematic studies using optical, electrochemical, and theoretical analyses reveal that functional group modifications on the acceptor significantly influenced the electronic properties, particularly tuning the HOMO–LUMO gap (2.8–3.1 eV). These variations affect charge transport and bistable switching characteristics. Electrochemical measurements confirm the ferrocene core's redox‐active nature and acceptor units’ key role in enabling bistability. Theoretical simulations further elucidate charge trapping and release mechanisms. Overall, this work highlights the potential of ferrocene‐based D–π–A systems for next‐generation organic memory devices and provides valuable insights into structure–property relationships governing device performance.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Transition‐Metal‐Free Alkynylthiolation of Tertiary α‐Carbonyl Bromides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Herein, a transition‐metal‐free alkynylthiolation of tertiary α‐carbonyl bromides with 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles is reported. Those reactions involve the in situ generation of alkynylthiolate anions from 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles in the presence of a base and then their halogenophilic nucleophilic substitution (SN2X) reactions. The exceptionally mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, and excellent functional group tolerance highlight the utility of this method to prepare privileged motifs from readily available 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles and tertiary α‐carbonyl bromides feedstocks.
Herein, a transition‐metal‐free alkynylthiolation of tertiary α‐carbonyl bromides with 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles is reported. Those reactions involve the in situ generation of alkynylthiolate anions from 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles in the presence of a base and then their halogenophilic nucleophilic substitution (SN2X) reactions. The exceptionally mild reaction conditions, broad substrate scope, and excellent functional group tolerance highlight the utility of this method to prepare privileged motifs from readily available 1,2,3‐thiadiazoles and tertiary α‐carbonyl bromides feedstocks. Gram‐scale reaction and diverse synthetic transformations convincingly demonstrate the synthetic potential of this method.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: How Additives Enable Site–Selective Hydrogen Atom Transfer in Alcohols: Critical Roles of Intrinsic Charge Transfer and Peripheral Electrostatic Interactions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Additives enable site‐selective hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) in alcohols by enhancing both through‐bond orbital interactions and through‐space electrostatic stabilization. Different additives regulate HAT selectivity through distinct mechanisms. While ZnCl2 promotes αCH activation primarily by strengthening orbital interactions, borinic acid and the H2PO4 anion facilitate αCH abstraction mainly via electrostatic stabilization.
The roles of different types of additives or cocatalysts in modulating the hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) process of alcohols are computationally investigated. The approach of energy decomposition analysis is employed to dissect intermolecular interactions between radicals and CH substrates, thereby identifying key factors governing HAT site selectivity. The results reveal that different additives can alter the intermolecular interactions, leading to distinct factors governing HAT site selectivity. Specifically, ZnCl2 promotes αCH bond activation by enhancing charge transfer from the αCH σ orbital to the singly occupied molecular orbital of nitrogen. Borinic acid and H2PO4 anion favor αCH abstraction by introducing peripheral electrostatic interactions that stabilize the positively charged radical species.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Unnatural Aplysiatoxin Analogs with High Affinity for Protein Kinase C
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
In the course of synthetic study of aplysiatoxin, a potent protein kinase C (PKC) activator, it is serendipitously found that a five‐membered ether 1 obtained as an undesired product from alkyne‐containing macrodiolide 2 with Au catalyst shows a high affinity for PKC. Synthesis of ten analogs lead to compound 26 showing a higher affinity to PKC.
Aplysiatoxin (ATX) is a marine polyketide macrodiolide and a potent activator of protein kinase C (PKC), which results in a variety of biological events, including inflammation and tumor promotion. This synthetic study of ATX leads to the serendipitous discovery of macrodiolide 1, which showed a high affinity for PKCδ despite having a different ring system to ATX. Here, the synthesis of ten analogs of 1 is reported, one of which, unsaturated macrodiolide 26, showed a higher affinity to PKC than compound 1.

Synthesis of ten analogs lead to compound 26 showing a higher affinity to PKC.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Role of Quantum Tunneling in Synthetic Organic Chemistry
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Quantum mechanical tunneling, an alternative reaction pathway to the classical thermal one, is rarely considered in organic synthesis. However, there is growing evidence of its profound impacts, for example, in limiting access to target molecules or determining reaction outcomes. This article highlights recent exemplary studies and explores how concepts like tunneling control and instability can inform synthesis design and optimization.
Quantum mechanical tunneling offers an alternative dynamical pathway to the classical (thermal) overcoming of energetic barriers, by penetrating these barriers instead. Recent years have shed light on its impact on organic synthesis in terms of kinetics, reaction outcomes, and lifetimes (and thus feasibility) of reactive intermediates or supposedly stable products. This concept article summarizes recent computational and experimental studies and illuminates how the insights from these studies, for example, regarding the concepts of tunneling control and instability, should inform synthesis design and optimization.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Transition‐Metal‐Catalyzed Convergent Synthesis of Heterocyclic Compounds via CH Activation/Cyclization: An Overview and Summary Toward Terminal Alkynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
This review provides a comprehensive overview of the current progress in tandem CH activation reactions involving terminal alkynes. It predominantly covers the synthesis of five‐ and six‐membered heterocycles, as well as fused heterocycles, with an emphasis on specific topics, including purely chemical synthesis, electrochemical synthesis, and enantioselective synthesis.
The development of one‐step transformations to heterocyclic compounds would considerably boost the synthetic efficiency in organic chemistry. In recent years, numerous examples of the transition‐metal‐catalyzed (TMC) CH activation/annulation strategy have been reported. Despite remarkable progress achieved with internal alkynes, allenes, and alkyne surrogates, terminal alkynes remain challenging substrates. Due to their relatively acidic terminal protons, terminal alkynes easily undergo alternative homocoupling reactions under commonly used oxidative conditions, exhibiting significant difficulties in CH functionalizations. To date, the CH activation involving terminal alkynes remains one of the most promising and appealing areas in organic synthesis. This review provides a comprehensive overview of the current progress in tandem CH activation reactions with terminal alkynes. With a strong emphasis on the catalysis of Rh and Co transition metals, it predominantly covers the synthesis of five‐, six‐membered heterocycles, and fused heterocycles. In this protocol, specific topics, such as purely chemical synthesis, electrochemical synthesis, and enantioselective synthesis, mechanistic details associated with the documented reactions are discussed. In addition, a tactical user guidance for terminal alkynes‐participated CH activation is also put forward.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Blue‐Light‐Induced Pd‐Catalyzed Quinolinamide‐Directed Regioselective C‐8 Benzylation of 1‐Naphthylamines Using Flow‐Generated Aryldiazomethanes in Batch and Continuous‐Flow
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A visible‐light‐promoted palladium‐catalyzed CH bond functionalization protocol for 1‐naphthylamine derivatives is reported, enabling efficient and regioselective synthesis of 8‐benzylated 1‐naphthylamides directly from aryl aldehydes via benzylic CH activation. Utilizing a bidentate directing group strategy, the reaction exhibits broad substrate tolerance with good‐to‐excellent yields. The methodology effectively combines photochemical reactivity with Pd catalysis in a flow microreactor setup, facilitating the capture and use of short‐lived reactive intermediates.
Herein, a continuous photo‐flow protocol for quinolinamide‐directed regioselective C‐8 benzylation of 1‐naphthylamine derivatives via CH bond functionalization with flow‐generated aryldiazomethanes is reported. A wide range of 8‐benzylated‐1‐naphthylamide products are afforded in satisfactory yields upon palladium catalysis via a bidentate directing process under illumination by 12 W blue light‐emitting diodes (450 nm). This mild, simple, and convenient synthetic method allows a wide range of easily handled aryl aldehydes, without the exclusion of either moisture or oxygen. This transformation is environmentally friendly and operationally simple, and it can be easily scaled up to the gram scale with good selectivity. Finally, an improved protocol for CH functionalization is described, which relies on the use of a continuous‐flow photo‐microreactor.

Utilizing a bidentate directing group strategy, the reaction exhibits broad substrate tolerance with good-to-excellent yields. The methodology effectively combines photochemical reactivity with Pd catalysis in a flow microreactor setup, facilitating the capture and use of short-lived reactive intermediates.


Herein, a continuous photo-flow protocol for quinolinamide-directed regioselective C-8 benzylation of 1-naphthylamine derivatives via CH bond functionalization with flow-generated aryldiazomethanes is reported. A wide range of 8-benzylated-1-naphthylamide products are afforded in satisfactory yields upon palladium catalysis via a bidentate directing process under illumination by 12 W blue light-emitting diodes (450 nm). This mild, simple, and convenient synthetic method allows a wide range of easily handled aryl aldehydes, without the exclusion of either moisture or oxygen. This transformation is environmentally friendly and operationally simple, and it can be easily scaled up to the gram scale with good selectivity. Finally, an improved protocol for CH functionalization is described, which relies on the use of a continuous-flow photo-microreactor.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A Greener Approach to 2,5‐Furandicarboxylate Macrocycles and their Entropically Driven Ring Opening Polymerization
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
2,5‐furandicarboxylic acid‐based polymers are obtained through the entropically driven ring‐opening polymerization of the corresponding macrocyclic oligoesters (MCOs). MCOs are synthesized using cyclopentyl methyl ether as a green solvent and purified without column chromatography. Properties of the resulting polyesters are evaluated and compared between the different techniques.
Thermoplastic polyesters (PEs), with their versatile properties, are indispensable in everyday life. However, increasing concerns about the environmental impact of fossil‐based polymers have driven research into renewable alternatives. Among bio‐based polymers, furan‐derived PEs such as poly(ethylene furanoate) (PEF) have garnered significant attention. The synthesis of PEF, as well as other similar 2,5‐furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA)‐based polymers, is mainly based on bulk polycondensation (PC) that in general requires elevated temperatures and low pressure, making the process energy‐intensive and vulnerable to thermo‐oxidative degradation. In this view, entropically driven ring opening polymerization (ED‐ROP) might represent an interesting potential alternative since it requires milder conditions and is intrinsically more atom economic. From these premises, this work focuses on developing an alternative synthetic strategy to bio‐based PEs through ED‐ROP of macrocycles derived from FDCA dimethyl ester (FDME). These macrocycles were prepared by reacting FDME with diols via pseudo‐high dilution condensation (PHDC) using dibutyltin(IV) oxide as a catalyst and cyclopentyl methyl ether as a recyclable green solvent. Isolation of the pure macrocycles is achieved by simple crystallization from the reaction mixture. Subsequent ROP of pure macrocycles is investigated as a viable route to prepare the related PEs in mild reaction conditions.
item.content:encoded:
2,5-furandicarboxylic acid-based polymers are obtained through the entropically driven ring-opening polymerization of the corresponding macrocyclic oligoesters (MCOs). MCOs are synthesized using cyclopentyl methyl ether as a green solvent and purified without column chromatography. Properties of the resulting polyesters are evaluated and compared between the different techniques.


Thermoplastic polyesters (PEs), with their versatile properties, are indispensable in everyday life. However, increasing concerns about the environmental impact of fossil-based polymers have driven research into renewable alternatives. Among bio-based polymers, furan-derived PEs such as poly(ethylene furanoate) (PEF) have garnered significant attention. The synthesis of PEF, as well as other similar 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA)-based polymers, is mainly based on bulk polycondensation (PC) that in general requires elevated temperatures and low pressure, making the process energy-intensive and vulnerable to thermo-oxidative degradation. In this view, entropically driven ring opening polymerization (ED-ROP) might represent an interesting potential alternative since it requires milder conditions and is intrinsically more atom economic. From these premises, this work focuses on developing an alternative synthetic strategy to bio-based PEs through ED-ROP of macrocycles derived from FDCA dimethyl ester (FDME). These macrocycles were prepared by reacting FDME with diols via pseudo-high dilution condensation (PHDC) using dibutyltin(IV) oxide as a catalyst and cyclopentyl methyl ether as a recyclable green solvent. Isolation of the pure macrocycles is achieved by simple crystallization from the reaction mixture. Subsequent ROP of pure macrocycles is investigated as a viable route to prepare the related PEs in mild reaction conditions.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of Novel BINOL Analogs: 3,3′‐Dicarbonyl‐1,1′‐binaphthyl‐4,4′‐diols as Precursors to the Uncharted 5,5′‐Binaphtho[2,1‐d]isoxazole
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The parent 5,5′‐binaphtho[2,1‐d]isoxazole and its 3,3′‐dimethyl and 3,3′‐diphenyl derivatives are synthesized via condensation of the respective dicarbonyl compounds with hydroxylamine, followed by cyclodehydration of the resulting dioximes. The dicarbonyl precursors are obtained through 4‐ or 6‐step sequences from 1‐naphthol or 1‐naphthaldehyde, involving oxidation, methylation, demethylation, coupling, bromination, formylation, esterification, and Fries rearrangement.
[1,1′‐Binaphthalene]‐2,2′‐diol (BINOL) analog, [1,1′‐binaphthalene]‐4,4′‐diol, obtained by direct oxidative coupling of 1‐naphthol, is acylated to [1,1′‐binaphthalene]‐4,4′‐diyl diacetate and then rearranged by the Fries reaction to 1,1'‐{4,4'‐dihydroxy‐[1,1'‐binaphthalene]‐3,3'‐diyl}bis(ethan‐1‐one). Incorporation of aldehyde groups at the 3,3' positions of [1,1′‐binaphthalene]‐4,4′‐diol required oxidative coupling of 1‐methoxynaphthalene to 4,4′‐dimethoxy‐1,1′‐binaphthalene, bromination, formylation, and demethylation. Incorporation of benzoyl groups at the 3,3' positions of [1,1′‐binaphthalene]‐4,4′‐diol required subjecting either 1‐(4‐bromo‐1‐hydroxy‐2‐naphthyl)(phenyl)methanone to the Ullmann reaction conditions or 4,4′‐dimethoxy‐1,1′‐binaphthalene to the Friedel–Crafts reaction with benzoyl chloride. The 1,1′‐(4,4′‐dihydroxy‐1,1′‐binaphthalene‐3,3′‐diyl)dicarbonyls are converted to the corresponding dioximes, which then underwent cyclodehydration to the respective novel 5,5'‐binaphtho[2,1‐d]isoxazoles.

The parent 5,5′-binaphtho[2,1-d]isoxazole and its 3,3′-dimethyl and 3,3′-diphenyl derivatives are synthesized via condensation of the respective dicarbonyl compounds with hydroxylamine, followed by cyclodehydration of the resulting dioximes. The dicarbonyl precursors are obtained through 4- or 6-step sequences from 1-naphthol or 1-naphthaldehyde, involving oxidation, methylation, demethylation, coupling, bromination, formylation, esterification, and Fries rearrangement.


[1,1′-Binaphthalene]-2,2′-diol (BINOL) analog, [1,1′-binaphthalene]-4,4′-diol, obtained by direct oxidative coupling of 1-naphthol, is acylated to [1,1′-binaphthalene]-4,4′-diyl diacetate and then rearranged by the Fries reaction to 1,1'-{4,4'-dihydroxy-[1,1'-binaphthalene]-3,3'-diyl}bis(ethan-1-one). Incorporation of aldehyde groups at the 3,3' positions of [1,1′-binaphthalene]-4,4′-diol required oxidative coupling of 1-methoxynaphthalene to 4,4′-dimethoxy-1,1′-binaphthalene, bromination, formylation, and demethylation. Incorporation of benzoyl groups at the 3,3' positions of [1,1′-binaphthalene]-4,4′-diol required subjecting either 1-(4-bromo-1-hydroxy-2-naphthyl)(phenyl)methanone to the Ullmann reaction conditions or 4,4′-dimethoxy-1,1′-binaphthalene to the Friedel–Crafts reaction with benzoyl chloride. The 1,1′-(4,4′-dihydroxy-1,1′-binaphthalene-3,3′-diyl)dicarbonyls are converted to the corresponding dioximes, which then underwent cyclodehydration to the respective novel 5,5'-binaphtho[2,1-d]isoxazoles.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Ultrasound‐Assisted In‐Water [3 + 2] Cycloaddition for the Synthesis of Fused Pyrrolizidine and Indolizidine Scaffolds with Anticancer Activity
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A sustainable, ultrasound‐assisted intramolecular (3 + 2) cycloaddition in water enables efficient one‐pot access to fused‐pyrrolizidine and indolizidine scaffolds. The method offers high atom economy, low E‐factor, and reveals a striking mechanistic divergence between ultrasound and thermal pathways. Its practicality is showcased through gram‐scale synthesis, late‐stage functionalization, and potent anticancer activity against triple‐negative breast cancer.
An ultrasound‐assisted in‐water intramolecular (3 + 2) cycloaddition reaction is reported for the synthesis of fused‐pyrrolizidine and indolizidine frameworks. This approach eliminates the need for organic solvents, harsh reagents, and high temperatures. The method's practicality is demonstrated by gram‐scale synthesis, and the anticancer properties of the resulting compounds against the triple‐negative breast cancer cell line are demonstrated.
item.content:encoded:
A sustainable, ultrasound-assisted intramolecular (3 + 2) cycloaddition in water enables efficient one-pot access to fused-pyrrolizidine and indolizidine scaffolds. The method offers high atom economy, low E-factor, and reveals a striking mechanistic divergence between ultrasound and thermal pathways. Its practicality is showcased through gram-scale synthesis, late-stage functionalization, and potent anticancer activity against triple-negative breast cancer.


An ultrasound-assisted in-water intramolecular (3 + 2) cycloaddition reaction is reported for the synthesis of fused-pyrrolizidine and indolizidine frameworks. This approach eliminates the need for organic solvents, harsh reagents, and high temperatures. The method's practicality is demonstrated by gram-scale synthesis, and the anticancer properties of the resulting compounds against the triple-negative breast cancer cell line are demonstrated.

item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Cyclization of Vinyl Isocyanides with Diaryl Disulfides/1,2‐Dialkyldiselanes for the Synthesis of 1‐Substituted Isoquinolines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A visible‐light‐induced tandem cyclization of vinyl isocyanides with diaryl disulfides or 1,2‐dialkyldiselanes has been realized for the first time. The reaction provides an environmentally friendly method for the synthesis of 1‐thio/selenoisoquinolines from the easily available starting materials in a single step.
Isoquinoline compounds, especially 1‐substituted derivatives, have garnered considerable attention due to their ubiquitous presence in natural products and pharmaceuticals. Herein, a novel visible‐light‐induced tandem cyclization of vinyl isocyanides with diaryl disulfides or 1,2‐dialkyldiselanes has been developed. The reaction tolerates a wide range of substrates and provides an environmentally friendly route to the synthesis of 1‐thio/selenoisoquinolines from the easily available starting materials in a single step.
item.content:encoded:

The reaction provides an environmentally friendly method for the synthesis of 1-thio/selenoisoquinolines from the easily available starting materials in a single step.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Modular Synthesis of 3,4‐Disubstituted Pyrroles Through Three‐Component Van Leusen Reaction of Propargylamines with Tosylmethyl Isocyanide and Water
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A novel three‐component strategy for the synthesis of valuable 3,4‐disubstituted pyrroles from easily available propargylamines, tosylmethyl isocyanide, and water in the presence of DBU has been developed.
A novel three‐component van Leusen strategy has been developed for the efficient and straightforward synthesis of valuable 3,4‐disubstituted pyrroles from easily available propargylamines, tosylmethyl isocyanide, and water. This transformation advances through the formation of a pyrrole framework via [3 + 2] cycloaddition with tosylmethyl isocyanide and a sequential nucleophilic substitution, ring‐opening, and deprotonation/protonation cascade process. This reaction provides a convenient modular access to pyrrole derivatives with aryl and benzoyl groups through the formation of three new bonds and one heterocycle from readily available acyclic precursors in a single step.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Palladium(II)‐Catalyzed Distal CH Functionalization of 8‐Aminoquinolinamides: Facile Synthesis of Triarylmethane Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The manuscript reports a chelation‐induced remote CH functionalization of 8‐aminoquinolinamides with p‐quinone methides as alkylating agents. The method enables efficient coupling across diverse quinolinamides, demonstrating broad substrate scope and excellent functional group tolerance.
Herein, a straightforward approach is reported for the palladium‐catalyzed oxidative remote CH alkylation of 8‐aminoquinoline derivatives using para‐quinone methides. This method enables selective C5‐alkylation of quinolines and exhibits a site‐selectivity distinct from that typically observed in convetional palladium‐catalyzed sp2 CH activation. The reaction proceeds via chelation‐induced remote CH functionalization, and a broad range of quinolinamides are successfully coupled with p‐quinone methides, demonstrating excellent substrate scope and functional group tolerance. Preliminary mechanistic studies suggest a reversible CH metalation step as part of the catalytic cycle.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Spiro[3.3]heptane: A Versatile sp3‐Rich Scaffold and its Synthetic Routes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The sp3‐rich spiro[3.3]heptane scaffold is a saturated, 3D bioisostere of benzene. This review summarizes key synthetic strategies, including [2+2] cyclizations and bond disconnections at C1C2 or C4 (spiro‐carbon) positions, offering a practical guide for accessing this emerging motif and expanding drug‐like chemical space.
Among the growing class of sp3‐rich scaffolds, spiro[3.3]heptane stands out for its rigid, 3D structure and favorable physicochemical properties. Its 3D saturated scaffold enables access to unique, nonplanar chemical space and has been explored as a saturated bioisostere of benzene in drug design. In this review, an overview of synthetic strategies developed to construct spiro[3.3]heptane derivatives is provided. These approaches are grouped according to key synthetic strategies, including formal [2+2] cyclization and bond disconnections at C1C2 or C4 (spiro‐carbon) positions. Representative examples are presented to illustrate each method's key transformations and strategic bond formations. This review is intended to support synthetic chemists interested in employing spiro[3.3]heptane as a building block and to provide a foundation for further exploration of this emerging motif.

This review is intended to support synthetic chemists interested in employing spiro[3.3]heptane as a building block and to provide a foundation for further exploration of this emerging motif.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A Density Functional Theory‐Genetic Algorithm Approach for the Structural Elucidation of Linear Diamantane Polyesters and their Nonlinear Optical Properties
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Diamondoid polyesters emit white light upon continuous infrared laser irradiation. The structures of the polyesters are microcrystalline as determined with solid‐state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy combined with computational analyzes.
We report a series of diamantane polyesters synthesized as head‐to‐head and side‐to‐side linear chain polymers. The incorporation of the bulky and rigid diamantyl moiety significantly enhances the thermal stabilities of these polymers compared to well‐established linear aliphatic polyesters, such as poly(ε‐caprolactone), poly(lactic acid), poly(butylene succinate), and poly(glycolic acid). This enhancement is confirmed by thermogravimetric analyzes, which show degradation onsets in the range of 520 to 580 °C. The structural characterization of these polyesters posed significant challenges due to virtual insolubility in organic solvents, limiting the use of techniques such as mass spectrometry and liquid‐state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. To address these challenges, a genetic algorithm for structure prediction based on periodic density functional theory computations was employed, yielding a structure that closely matches the powder X‐ray diffraction data. Heavily constrained Rietveld refinement provided excellent agreement with the experimental results. These findings, combined with solid‐state NMR data, have been integrated to provide a comprehensive understanding of the polyester properties. These polyesters demonstrate promising nonlinear optical responses, including white‐light emission upon continuous infrared laser irradiation, making them candidates for optoelectronic applications.
item.content:encoded:
Diamondoid polyesters emit white light upon continuous infrared laser irradiation. The structures of the polyesters are microcrystalline as determined with solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy combined with computational analyzes.


We report a series of diamantane polyesters synthesized as head-to-head and side-to-side linear chain polymers. The incorporation of the bulky and rigid diamantyl moiety significantly enhances the thermal stabilities of these polymers compared to well-established linear aliphatic polyesters, such as poly(ε-caprolactone), poly(lactic acid), poly(butylene succinate), and poly(glycolic acid). This enhancement is confirmed by thermogravimetric analyzes, which show degradation onsets in the range of 520 to 580 °C. The structural characterization of these polyesters posed significant challenges due to virtual insolubility in organic solvents, limiting the use of techniques such as mass spectrometry and liquid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. To address these challenges, a genetic algorithm for structure prediction based on periodic density functional theory computations was employed, yielding a structure that closely matches the powder X-ray diffraction data. Heavily constrained Rietveld refinement provided excellent agreement with the experimental results. These findings, combined with solid-state NMR data, have been integrated to provide a comprehensive understanding of the polyester properties. These polyesters demonstrate promising nonlinear optical responses, including white-light emission upon continuous infrared laser irradiation, making them candidates for optoelectronic applications.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: 1,2‐Sulfonylative‐Arylation of Acrylamides via Strain‐Release‐/Aromaticity‐Driven Radical Generation and SO2‐Capture under Photoredox Catalysis to Access S(VI)‐Oxindoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
1,2‐Sulfonylative‐arylation of N‐phenyl acrylamides has been achieved under visible‐light photoredox catalysis conditions. Strained 3°‐cyclopropanols and 4‐alkyl‐1,4‐DHPs are exploited to trigger the acrylamide bisfunctionalization in the presence of SO2 for accessing S(VI) functionalized oxindoles bearing a β‐all‐carbon quaternary center in moderate to good yields.
γ‐Keto sulfones, despite being a medicinally relevant building block, have never been integrated with the bioactive oxindole scaffold present in several alkaloid natural products. On the other hand, strategies involving SO2 capture in organic molecules to access value‐added products are gaining momentum. Therefore, a strategy en route to γ‐keto alkylsulfonylated oxindoles bearing a β‐all‐carbon quaternary center is disclosed. Toward this goal, the bisfunctionalization of N‐(hetero)arylacrylamides has been realized via the strain‐release driven ring‐scission of strained 3°‐cyclopropanols in the presence of DABSO under visible‐light photoredox catalysis to access a library of γ‐keto alkylsulfonylated oxindoles. Also, the aromaticity‐driven bond‐scission in pro‐aromatics like 4‐alkyl‐1,4‐DHPs in the presence of Na2S2O5 under visible‐light photoredox catalysis has been exploited to trigger the alkylsulfonylative‐arylation of N‐(hetero)arylacrylamides to access a library of alkylsulfonylated oxindoles featuring a β‐all‐carbon quaternary center. Broad substrate scope is demonstrated, and the mechanistic probing studies have been complemented with DFT calculations. Also, moderate to potent cytotoxic activity is observed against the tested triple‐negative breast cancer cell lines for some of the synthesized sulfonylated oxindole derivatives. Further, evaluation of the mechanism of cell death for the most potent oxindole analog revealed that it induces apoptosis in a concentration‐dependent manner.
item.content:encoded:

Strained 3°-cyclopropanols and 4-alkyl-1,4-DHPs are exploited to trigger the acrylamide bisfunctionalization in the presence of SO2 for accessing S(VI) functionalized oxindoles bearing a β-all-carbon quaternary center in moderate to good yields.


γ-Keto sulfones, despite being a medicinally relevant building block, have never been integrated with the bioactive oxindole scaffold present in several alkaloid natural products. On the other hand, strategies involving SO2 capture in organic molecules to access value-added products are gaining momentum. Therefore, a strategy en route to γ-keto alkylsulfonylated oxindoles bearing a β-all-carbon quaternary center is disclosed. Toward this goal, the bisfunctionalization of N-(hetero)arylacrylamides has been realized via the strain-release driven ring-scission of strained 3°-cyclopropanols in the presence of DABSO under visible-light photoredox catalysis to access a library of γ-keto alkylsulfonylated oxindoles. Also, the aromaticity-driven bond-scission in pro-aromatics like 4-alkyl-1,4-DHPs in the presence of Na2S2O5 under visible-light photoredox catalysis has been exploited to trigger the alkylsulfonylative-arylation of N-(hetero)arylacrylamides to access a library of alkylsulfonylated oxindoles featuring a β-all-carbon quaternary center. Also, moderate to potent cytotoxic activity is observed against the tested triple-negative breast cancer cell lines for some of the synthesized sulfonylated oxindole derivatives. Further, evaluation of the mechanism of cell death for the most potent oxindole analog revealed that it induces apoptosis in a concentration-dependent manner.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A New Paradigm for the Supramolecular Structure of Laterally Offset Diarenes: Polymorphs II of Para‐Substituted Acetophenone Azines, YpPh(Me)CNNC(Me)PhYp (Y = Cl, Br, CH3)
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
While polymorphs I contain C2‐symmetric enantiomers with pronounced azine twists and disrotatory phenyl twists, the acetophenone azine molecules in the new polymorphs II are Ci‐symmetric with trans azine moieties and conrotatory phenyl twists. The three polymorphs II exemplify the new Paradigm IV for the supramolecular architectures of “laterally offset diarenes” and result in “shiplap/flat” idioteloamphiphile monolayers (IAMs).
The crystal structures of polymorphs II of acetophenone azines YpPhRCNNCRPhYp with R = CH3 and Y = Cl (1M), Br (2M), and CH3 (8M) are discussed. The azine molecules in polymorphs II are Ci‐symmetric with trans‐azine moieties and conrotatory phenyl twists. Polymorphs 1M‐I and 2M‐I contain C2‐symmetric enantiomers with pronounced azine twists and disrotatory phenyl twists and allow for strong lateral double T‐contacts. The three polymorphs II exemplify the new Paradigm IV for the supramolecular architectures of “laterally offset diarenes” and result in “shiplap/flat” idioteloamphiphile monolayers. Intralayer lateral attraction is provided by edge‐to‐face arene‐arene contacts between molecules with substantial longitudinal offset and involves arene edges bridging one azine‐N and one phenyl center (EAzArB synthon) or one phenyl center and substituent Y (EYArB synthon) of different neighbors. These bridging synthons are characterized by a survey of pertinent structure parameters and their structural significance is corroborated by analysis of distance mapped Hirshfeld surfaces and the computation of 2D‐fingerprint plots. The edge‐to‐face contacts are the most attractive intermolecular interactions, and these interactions are quantified via the computed pair interaction energies and the results of aromatic analyzer analysis. Synthon binding energies and lattice energies are determined to assess polymorph preference energies.
item.content:encoded:

The three polymorphs II exemplify the new Paradigm IV for the supramolecular architectures of “laterally offset diarenes” and result in “shiplap/flat” idioteloamphiphile monolayers (IAMs).

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iron‐Doped Hydrotalcite: A Heterogeneous Catalyst for the Selective Synthesis of 2‐Substituted Benzimidazoles and Benzothiazoles Using Alcohols and Solvent‐Free Reaction Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Iron‐doped calcium aluminium hydrotalcite was synthesised and employed for the selective synthesis of 2‐substituted benzimidazoles and benzothiazoles. The developed protocol uses low oxidation chemicals (alcohols) under solvent‐free reaction conditions, recyclable catalyst and broad substrate scope. Mechanistic study provides an insight into the mechanism of the reaction.
A heterogeneous iron‐anchored calcium aluminum hydrotalcite is prepared and characterized appropriately using powder X‐Ray diffraction, scanning electron microscope, energy dispersive X‐Ray, transmission electron microscope, ourier‐transform infrared, and thermogravimetric analysis. Further, X‐Ray photoelectron spectroscopy confirms the presence of Fe in +3 oxidation state. The prepared heterogeneous catalyst is applied to the selective synthesis of 2‐substituted benzimidazole and benzothiazole derivatives using alcohols and under solvent‐free reaction conditions. The developed protocol is applicable to a broad range of substrates, including difficult aliphatic substrates. The Fe/CaAl hydrotalcite catalyst can also be recycled and reused effectively for two catalytic cycles. Furthermore, control experiments reveal the role of the catalyst and the plausible mechanistic pathway of the reaction.
item.content:encoded:

Mechanistic study provides an insight into the mechanism of the reaction.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: A Family of Methylene‐Bridged Fully Functionalized Polynitroarenes and Tetrazole‐Based Energetic Materials
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The synthesis of methylene‐bridged fully functionalized polynitroarenes and tetrazole‐based energetic materials is reported. This approach enables the modification of the energetic properties of polynitroarenes by mono‐ and tricationic salt formation.
Herein, to fine‐tune the energetic properties of 2,4,6‐trinitrobenzene‐1,3‐diamine/diol, these are combined with tetrazole via a methylene bridge. This strategy unlocks the tunability of polynitroarenes performances via salt formation, which is restricted in directly CN connected polynitroarenes and azole derivatives. The amino/hydroxy functionalities between the nitro groups on the benzene ring provide extensive inter‐ and intramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions, contributing to improved stability, whereas the tetrazole ring increases the nitrogen percentage and energetic performance. Due to the presence of one and three labile protons in the amino derivative (compounds 4) and hydroxy derivative (compounds 5), respectively, a series of mono‐ and tricationic salts are prepared to further fine‐tune the overall performances. Among all the synthesized compounds, the tricationic energetic salt 10 (Dv = 8135 m s−1, IS > 40 J) exhibits energetic performance comparable to TATB and is insensitive. All the compounds are characterized through infrared spectroscopy, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, differential scanning calorimetry, elemental analysis, and high‐resolution mass spectra studies. The relationship between structure and properties is further explored using Hirshfeld surface, noncovalent interaction, Localized Orbital Locator (LOL)‐π, and electrostatic potential analysis.
item.content:encoded:

Due to the presence of one and three labile protons in the amino derivative (compounds 4) and hydroxy derivative (compounds 5), respectively, a series of mono- and tricationic salts are prepared to further fine-tune the overall performances. Among all the synthesized compounds, the tricationic energetic salt 10 (Dv = 8135 m s−1, IS > 40 J) exhibits energetic performance comparable to TATB and is insensitive.
